definitions: divide something that has already been divided into smaller sections or units
legally divide property or land into smaller plots for sale or development
examples: The company will subdivide the project into manageable phases
We need to subdivide this large task into smaller components
The developer plans to subdivide the estate into residential lots
They received permission to subdivide the farmland for housing

definitions: defeat someone or bring them under control using physical force or authority
make something less strong intense or violent in effect or degree
control or suppress strong emotions or reactions within oneself or others
examples: The police managed to subdue the violent protesters peacefully
Ancient armies would subdue neighboring territories through conquest
The medication helped subdue the severe pain considerably
Soft lighting can subdue harsh colors in interior design
She struggled to subdue her anger during the meeting
He tried to subdue his excitement before the announcement

definitions: cause someone or something to undergo or experience something typically unpleasant
bring a person or country under one's control or jurisdiction typically by conquest
examples: The researchers will subject the materials to extreme temperatures
Don't subject yourself to unnecessary stress and pressure
The empire sought to subject neighboring kingdoms through military force
The colonizers attempted to subject the indigenous population

definitions: bring under domination or control especially by conquest or military force
make someone or something subordinate to or dependent upon something else
examples: The invading army sought to subjugate the entire region
Throughout history empires have tried to subjugate other nations
The corporation aims to subjugate smaller competitors through aggressive tactics
He refused to subjugate his principles to political expediency

definitions: rent property from a tenant rather than directly from the owner
lease or rent all or part of a leased property to another person
examples: She decided to sublet an apartment from her friend
Many students sublet rooms during the summer months
I plan to sublet my apartment while traveling abroad
The tenant cannot sublet without the landlord's permission

definitions: go below the surface of water or another liquid completely
cause something to go completely below the surface of water or liquid
completely cover suppress or overwhelm something making it disappear from view
examples: The submarine can submerge to depths of three hundred meters
The whale will submerge for up to twenty minutes
Please submerge the vegetables in cold water immediately
The flood waters will submerge the entire valley
Don't let work pressures submerge your personal life completely
The artist chose to submerge her identity in the collective

definitions: present a proposal application or other document to a person or body for consideration
accept or yield to a superior force or to the authority of another person
send or transfer data or documents electronically through a system or platform
examples: Please submit your report by Friday afternoon
All students must submit their essays before the deadline
The defendant finally agreed to submit to the court's authority
She refused to submit to their unreasonable demands
Click here to submit the online application form
You can submit your tax return electronically this year

definitions: treat or regard something as less important than something else in priority or emphasis
place someone in a lower rank or position within an organizational hierarchy
examples: You should not subordinate safety concerns to profit margins
The director tends to subordinate character development to visual effects
The company will subordinate new hires to experienced team leaders
Military structure requires soldiers to subordinate themselves to commanding officers

definitions: order someone to attend a court of law to give evidence or produce documents
legally require the production of documents or evidence for a legal proceeding
examples: The prosecutor will subpoena three witnesses for the trial
The court can subpoena anyone with relevant information
The committee voted to subpoena financial records from the corporation
Lawyers may subpoena emails and text messages as evidence

definitions: arrange to receive something regularly typically a publication by paying in advance
sign up to receive regular updates notifications or content from a service or platform
express agreement with or support for an idea opinion or belief
sign one's name formally on a document as a witness or to show agreement
examples: I subscribe to several scientific journals every year
Many people subscribe to streaming services for entertainment
Please subscribe to our newsletter for weekly updates
Over a million users subscribe to her YouTube channel
I cannot subscribe to such an extreme political view
Most experts subscribe to the theory of climate change
All parties must subscribe their names to the contract
Witnesses were required to subscribe the legal document

definitions: become less intense violent or severe gradually over time until calm
sink to a lower or normal level especially of water or ground
sink or settle down into a more stable or calm position or state
examples: The storm will subside by tomorrow morning
Her anger began to subside after the explanation
Flood waters are expected to subside within two days
The swelling should subside after taking the medication
The protests gradually subsided after the government's announcement
Market volatility tends to subside after major elections

definitions: support an organization or activity financially especially with government funds
pay part of the cost of something to reduce the price for the buyer
examples: The government will subsidise renewable energy projects this year
Many countries subsidise their agricultural sectors heavily
The company subsidises employee gym memberships and health insurance
Universities often subsidise student housing to make it affordable

definitions: support an organization or activity financially especially with government funds
pay part of the cost of something to reduce the price for the buyer
examples: The state will subsidize public transportation to reduce traffic
Federal programs subsidize farming in rural areas
Employers often subsidize health insurance for their workers
The university subsidizes meals in student cafeterias

definitions: maintain or support oneself at a minimal level with limited resources
survive by maintaining oneself on particular food or resources
remain in being or continue to exist especially in difficult circumstances
examples: Many families subsist on less than two dollars per day
The refugees had to subsist in harsh conditions
The tribe continues to subsist on hunting and gathering
Some animals can subsist on very little water
Ancient traditions still subsist in remote mountain villages
The agreement will subsist until formally terminated

definitions: provide evidence or proof to support or prove the truth of a claim
establish the accuracy or validity of something through factual support
give actual form or substance to something abstract or theoretical
examples: The lawyer must substantiate these allegations with concrete evidence
Research data will substantiate our hypothesis about climate patterns
Can you substantiate your claims about the product's effectiveness?
Historical documents substantiate the author's controversial theory
The architect's plans substantiate her vision for sustainable design
These findings substantiate what we suspected all along

definitions: use or add something in place of another thing typically of lesser quality
act or serve as a replacement for someone in their absence or role
exchange one thing for another especially to achieve a similar result
examples: You can substitute honey for sugar in this recipe
The coach will substitute the injured player immediately
Sarah will substitute for the regular teacher next week
An assistant can substitute when the manager is away
We need to substitute outdated equipment with modern technology
The company plans to substitute plastic with biodegradable materials

definitions: add captions displaying dialogue or translation at the bottom of a screen
give a secondary or explanatory title to a book article or work
examples: The studio will subtitle the film in twelve languages
Someone needs to subtitle these educational videos for accessibility
The author decided to subtitle her book for clarity
Publishers often subtitle academic works with descriptive phrases

definitions: take away a number or amount from another to calculate the difference
remove or take away something from a total or whole
examples: Students learn to subtract double-digit numbers in second grade
Please subtract the discount from the original price
We need to subtract travel expenses from the budget
The bank will subtract fees from your account monthly

definitions: undermine the power and authority of an established system or institution
corrupt or destroy something from within often gradually and secretly
examples: Rebel forces attempted to subvert the government through propaganda
Foreign agents tried to subvert the democratic process
The virus can subvert the computer's security systems completely
Negative attitudes can subvert team morale and productivity

definitions: accomplish an aim or purpose achieving the desired or intended result
come next after something or someone in time order or position
take over a position role or title from someone else through inheritance
examples: She worked hard to succeed in her business venture
The team finally succeeded after months of preparation
Spring will succeed winter as the seasons change
Chapter five succeeds the introduction in this textbook
Prince William will succeed to the throne after his father
The vice president succeeded the retiring CEO last month

definitions: fail to resist pressure temptation or some other negative force
die from the effect of a disease or injury
examples: She finally succumbed to peer pressure and joined them
Don't succumb to the temptation of easy money
Many patients succumb to the disease within months
The wounded soldier succumbed to his injuries overnight

definitions: draw into the mouth by creating a partial vacuum with lips and tongue
draw something in a particular direction by creating a vacuum or partial vacuum
be very bad unpleasant or disappointing in quality or nature
examples: The baby learned to suck milk from a bottle
Children often suck their thumbs for comfort
The vacuum cleaner will suck up all the dirt
The whirlpool can suck boats under the surface
This movie really sucks compared to the original
Having to work on weekends really sucks

definitions: remove or draw out something using the force of suction or vacuum
cause something to adhere to a surface using vacuum or suction force
examples: The dentist will suction excess saliva during the procedure
Surgeons suction blood from the surgical site continuously
The device can suction onto smooth surfaces securely
These cups suction to the windshield for mounting

definitions: institute legal proceedings against a person or institution typically for redress
make a formal petition or appeal for something to an authority
examples: The company plans to sue for breach of contract
She decided to sue her employer for discrimination
The defendant will sue for peace after years of conflict
Prisoners may sue for their constitutional rights

definitions: experience or be subjected to physical or mental pain
experience or be subjected to something bad or unpleasant
become worse in quality condition or effectiveness as a result
tolerate or allow something to exist or happen despite disapproval
examples: Patients suffer terrible pain without proper medication
She continues to suffer from chronic migraines
The region will suffer severe drought this summer
Many businesses suffered huge losses during the recession
Your grades will suffer if you don't study regularly
Team performance suffered after losing key players
The board will not suffer such incompetence any longer
Ancient rulers would not suffer dissent among subjects

definitions: be enough or adequate for a particular purpose or requirement
meet the needs or requirements of a situation without excess
examples: A simple explanation will suffice for now
Two examples should suffice to illustrate the point
These supplies must suffice until the delivery arrives
Her modest income suffices for basic necessities

definitions: add a suffix or ending to a word to modify its meaning
add or append something to the end of another thing
examples: In English we suffix '-ed' to create past tense
Linguists study how languages suffix words for grammar
Please suffix your employee ID to all documents
The system will suffix a timestamp to each file

definitions: die or cause to die from lack of air or inability to breathe
kill someone by depriving them of air or preventing them from breathing
feel trapped and oppressed as if unable to breathe freely
examples: People can suffocate in confined spaces without ventilation
The smoke was so thick we nearly suffocated
The killer tried to suffocate his victim with a pillow
Weeds can suffocate garden plants by blocking sunlight
She felt suffocated by her controlling family members
Corporate bureaucracy can suffocate creativity and innovation

definitions: add sugar to food or drink to make it taste sweeter
make something more pleasant or acceptable often by disguising harsh realities
examples: She prefers to sugar her coffee in the morning
Don't sugar the berries until serving time
Politicians often sugar their messages to avoid controversy
There's no way to sugar the bad news

definitions: put forward for consideration a proposal or plan for others to think about
indicate the truth or existence of something without stating it directly
cause one to think of something because of similarity or association
examples: I suggest we meet next Tuesday to discuss this
The doctor suggested trying a different medication
The evidence suggests he was lying about his whereabouts
Her tone suggested she was unhappy with the decision
The painting suggests a peaceful countryside scene
This music suggests the atmosphere of medieval times

definitions: be convenient for or acceptable to someone's needs or preferences
enhance the appearance features or figure of someone by matching well
please or satisfy someone by meeting their requirements or wishes
examples: Monday doesn't suit me for the meeting
This job would suit someone with your skills perfectly
That color really suits your complexion beautifully
Short hair suits her face shape very well
You can't suit everyone with your decisions
The arrangement suits both parties involved equally

definitions: damage the purity or integrity of someone's reputation or character
make something dirty or stained especially something previously clean
examples: The scandal will sully his reputation permanently
False accusations can sully an innocent person's name
Children quickly sully their clean clothes at play
Industrial waste continues to sully the pristine river

definitions: calculate the total of two or more numbers or amounts
give a brief statement of the main points of something
examples: Please sum all the expenses for this month
The accountant will sum the quarterly revenue figures
Let me sum up the main arguments presented today
The judge will sum up before the jury deliberates

definitions: give a brief statement or account of the main points of something
present the essential features of something in a condensed form
examples: Please summarize the report in two paragraphs
The professor asked students to summarize each chapter
Can you summarize the meeting for those who missed it?
The article summarizes recent developments in technology

definitions: spend the summer season in a particular place or way
keep or maintain animals in a particular place during summer months
examples: Wealthy families often summer in the Hamptons
We plan to summer abroad in Southern France
Farmers summer their cattle in mountain pastures
The sheep will summer on the higher slopes

definitions: reach the highest point or top of a mountain or hill
participate in or organize a meeting between heads of government
examples: The climbers hope to summit before noon tomorrow
Only experienced mountaineers should attempt to summit Everest
World leaders will summit next month about climate change
The presidents plan to summit regarding trade agreements

definitions: authoritatively call someone to be present especially for legal proceedings
call upon or gather one's strength courage or resources for an effort
cause a quality or memory to come to mind or be present
examples: The court will summon witnesses to testify next week
The principal summoned the students to her office
She had to summon all her courage to speak publicly
The team summoned their remaining strength for the final push
The old photograph summoned memories of childhood summers
His words summoned images of distant lands

definitions: expose something to the sun's rays typically to warm or dry it
sit or lie in the sun especially to warm oneself or get a tan
examples: She likes to sun her laundry on the clothesline
Turtles sun themselves on rocks near the pond
People sun themselves on the beach all afternoon
The cat loves to sun in the window

definitions: suffer from reddening and inflammation of skin caused by overexposure to sun
cause skin to become red and inflamed through excessive exposure to sunlight
examples: Fair-skinned people sunburn easily without protection
I sunburned badly after forgetting sunscreen yesterday
The tropical sun can sunburn exposed skin within minutes
Don't let the children sunburn at the beach

definitions: split apart or break into pieces especially with great force
break apart a relationship or connection between people or things
examples: The earthquake will sunder the ground along fault lines
Lightning can sunder trees with tremendous force
War tends to sunder families and communities permanently
Political differences sundered their long friendship

definitions: take liquid into the mouth in small quantities typically with a spoon
eat supper or the evening meal especially in a formal or old-fashioned context
examples: The patient could only sup warm broth slowly
Children learn to sup soup without spilling
We shall sup at eight o'clock this evening
The family sups together every Sunday night

definitions: take the place of something previously in authority or use by being superior
replace a person or thing previously holding a position or role
examples: Digital technology will supersede analog systems completely
New safety regulations supersede all previous guidelines
The new manager will supersede the retiring director
This agreement supersedes any prior verbal commitments

definitions: observe and direct the execution of a task project or activity
watch over and guide someone in their work or activities
examples: She will supervise the construction project until completion
Managers supervise daily operations in the warehouse
Parents should supervise young children near water
Graduate students supervise undergraduate lab sessions

definitions: forcefully take the place of someone or something often by scheming
supersede and replace something especially through superior merit or power
examples: The ambitious prince sought to supplant his brother
New technology threatens to supplant traditional methods
Digital books may supplant printed ones eventually
Synthetic materials supplant natural fibers in manufacturing

definitions: make something soft flexible and able to bend easily without breaking
become soft flexible and pliant through treatment or exercise
examples: Regular stretching will supple stiff muscles effectively
Oil treatments help supple dry leather goods
Your joints will supple with daily yoga practice
The material supples after proper conditioning treatment

definitions: add an extra element or amount to something to improve or complete it
provide something additional to enhance or extend what already exists
examples: Many students supplement their income with part-time work
Vitamins can supplement a healthy diet effectively
The company will supplement employee salaries with bonuses
Online resources supplement traditional classroom teaching methods

definitions: provide someone with something that is needed or wanted
make something needed or wanted available to someone
take over someone's role or position temporarily as a substitute
examples: The company supplies parts to major manufacturers
Local farms supply fresh produce to area restaurants
The dam supplies water to three counties
This printer supplies excellent color reproduction
She will supply for the math teacher next week
Ministers often supply at neighboring churches

definitions: bear all or part of the weight of something to hold it up
give assistance encouragement or approval to someone or something
provide with necessities of life especially financially
confirm or give evidence for the truth or validity of something
examples: These pillars support the entire roof structure
The bridge can support heavy truck traffic
Parents should support their children's educational goals
I support the new environmental protection policy
He works two jobs to support his family
Government grants support important research projects
Scientific data supports the new climate theory
These findings support our initial hypothesis completely

definitions: assume that something is the case without proof for argument or explanation
think or believe something to be true or probable based on incomplete evidence
require or imply as a necessary condition or logical consequence
examples: Let's suppose the hypothesis is correct
Suppose we leave at dawn tomorrow morning
I suppose she forgot about our meeting
Many people suppose him to be wealthy
Success supposes hard work and dedication
This theory supposes the existence of dark matter

definitions: forcibly put an end to something such as a rebellion or opposition
prevent the expression development or visibility of feelings or information
consciously keep unpleasant thoughts or feelings from entering awareness
examples: The government tried to suppress the peaceful protests
Military forces were sent to suppress the rebellion
She struggled to suppress her tears during the ceremony
The company attempted to suppress negative news reports
He tends to suppress painful childhood memories
Some people suppress their true feelings constantly
